original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āraññako mago abaddho pāsarāsiṁ adhisayeyya.🔽So evamassa veditabbo:
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave āraññakaḥ magaḥ a baddhaḥ pāsara asim adhisayeyya  saḥ evam assa veditabbaḥ
translated: They are like a forest deer untied, untethered, wandering and grazing at will.

original: ‘na anayamāpanno na byasanamāpanno na yathākāmakaraṇīyo luddassa.
analyzed: na anayam āpannaḥ na byasanam āpannaḥ na yathākāma karaṇīyaḥ luddassa
translated: They should be understood to have not fallen into misfortune and calamity, and the hunter has no advantage over them.

original: Āgacchante ca pana ludde yena kāmaṁ pakkamissatī’ti.🔽Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ime pañca kāmaguṇe agathitā amucchitā anajjhopannā ādīnavadassāvino nissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjanti, te evamassu veditabbā:
analyzed: āgacchante ca pana ludde yena kāmam pakkamissati iti  evam eva kho bhikkhave ye hi keci samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā ime pañca kāmaguṇe a gathitāḥ a mucchitāḥ an ajjhopannāḥ ādīnava dassāvinaḥ nissaraṇa paññā paribhuñjanti te evam assu veditabbā
translated: And when the hunter comes, they will go wherever they like.

original: ‘na anayamāpannā na byasanamāpannā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā pāpimato’.
analyzed: na anayam āpannā na byasanam āpannā na yathā kāma karaṇīyā
translated: So too, any ascetics and brahmins who use these five cords of sensual pleasure without being tied to them, infatuated with them, blindly absorbed in them, utterly confused about them, not seeing the danger in them, not understanding the escape from them, should be understood to have not fallen into misfortune and calamity, and Māra has no advantage over them.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āraññako mago araññe pavane caramāno vissattho gacchati, vissattho tiṭṭhati, vissattho nisīdati, vissattho seyyaṁ kappeti.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave āraññakaḥ magaḥ araññe pavane caramānaḥ vissatthaḥ gacchati vissatthaḥ tiṭṭhati vissatthaḥ nisīdati vissatthaḥ seyyam kappeti
translated: Just as a forest deer wandering and ranging in the forest goes confidently, stands confidently, sits confidently, lies down confidently;

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: why is that?

original: Anāpāthagato, bhikkhave, luddassa.
analyzed: anāpātha gataḥ bhikkhave luddassa
translated: Because it is out of the hunter’s range.

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: So too, a bhikkhu, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, enters and dwells in the first jhana, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by thought and examination.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu andhamakāsi māraṁ apadaṁ, vadhitvā māracakkhuṁ adassanaṁ gato pāpimato.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave bhikkhu vadhitvā māra cakkhum adassanam gataḥ pāpimataḥ
translated: This bhikkhu is said to have blinded Mara, to have escaped the range of the Evil One, to have crossed the threshold, to have reached the threshold of heaven.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the second jhana, which has self-confidence and singleness of mind without thought and examination, with rapture and pleasure born of concentration.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave …pe… pāpimato.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave pe pāpimataḥ
translated: This bhikkhu is said to have blinded Mara, to have escaped the range of the Evil One, to have crossed the threshold, to have reached the threshold of heaven.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca🔽sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti ‘upekkhako satimā
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca  sampajānaḥ sukham ca kāyena paṭisavedeti yam tam ariyāḥ ācikkhanti upekkhakaḥ satimā
translated: “Again, bhikkhus, with the fading away as well of rapture, a bhikkhu abides in equanimity, and mindful and fully aware, still feeling pleasure with the body, he enters upon and abides in the third jhana, on account of which noble ones announce: ‘He has a pleasant abiding who has equanimity and is mindful.’

original: sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sukha vihārī iti tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the fading away as well of rapture, a bhikkhu abides in equanimity, and mindful and fully aware, still feeling pleasure with the body, he enters upon and abides in the third jhana, on account of which noble ones announce: ‘He has a pleasant abiding who has equanimity and is mindful.’

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave …pe… pāpimato.🔽Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave pe pāpimataḥ  puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā iva somanassa domanassāna
translated: This is called a footprint of the bhikkhu who has destroyed the taints.

original: atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: atthaṅgamā adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous passing away of joy and displeasure, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the fourth jhana, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave …pe… pāpimato.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave pe pāpimataḥ
translated: This is called a footprint of the bhikkhu who has destroyed the taints.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, by completely surmounting the base of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite,’ a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the base of infinite consciousness.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave …pe… pāpimato.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave pe pāpimataḥ
translated: This, monks, is called a bad person.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the complete surmounting of the base of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite,’ a monk enters and dwells in the base of infinite consciousness.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave …pe… pāpimato.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave pe pāpimataḥ
translated: This, monks, is called a bad person.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the complete surmounting of the base of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing,’ a monk enters and dwells in the base of nothingness.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave …pe… pāpimato.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave pe pāpimataḥ
translated: This, monks, is called a bad person.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the complete surmounting of the base of nothingness, a monk enters and dwells in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave …pe… pāpimato.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave pe pāpimataḥ
translated: This, monks, is called a bad person.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu sabbasas nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam samatikkamma saññā vedayita nirodham upasampajja viharati paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti
translated: “Again, with the complete surmounting of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, a monk enters and dwells in the cessation of perception and feeling. And his taints are destroyed by his seeing with wisdom.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu andhamakāsi māraṁ apadaṁ, vadhitvā māracakkhuṁ adassanaṁ gato pāpimato.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave bhikkhu vadhitvā māra cakkhum adassanam gataḥ pāpimataḥ
translated: This is said to be a monk who has blinded Māra, who has made Māra’s eye go blind, who has made Māra’s eye disappear.

original: Tiṇṇo loke visattikaṁ vissattho gacchati, vissattho tiṭṭhati, vissattho nisīdati, vissattho seyyaṁ kappeti.
analyzed: tiṇṇaḥ loke visattikam vissatthaḥ gacchati vissatthaḥ tiṭṭhati vissatthaḥ nisīdati vissatthaḥ seyyam kappeti
translated: He has crossed over the world’s entanglements. He goes confidently, stands confidently, sits confidently, lies down confidently.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Anāpāthagato, bhikkhave, pāpimato”ti.
analyzed: anāpātha gataḥ bhikkhave pāpimataḥ ti
translated: Because the Wicked One has no access.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.🔽Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān  attamanāḥ te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandunti
translated: The Fortunate One said this.

original: Pāsarāsisuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ chaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: pāsarāsi suttam niṭṭhitam chaṭṭha
translated: The monks were uplifted and greatly rejoiced in what was said by the Fortunate One.
